I'm jumping into this conversation late, but I have a slightly 
different p=
erspective:

In my experience, randomness should be minimized unless it is =

demonstrably necessary.  There is a kind of "law of deterministic 
general=
ization" that is useful to keep in mind:

"If the easiest way to solve a pr=
oblem is the most general way, then 
training determistically will lead to =
the most general solution 
without the need for randomness."

In other wors=
ds, in *some* problems, it is easier to learn a general 
technique than it =
is to memorize a trial-specific heuristic.  Easier 
means basically that th=
e general solution is simpler.  In that case, 
even a deterministic trainin=
g regimen will lead to the general 
solution because it is the easiest way =
to solve the problem 
regardless.  That means that in such a problem you *s=
hould* train 
deterministically (or almost so) because the only thing rando=
mness 
can do is add noise to the evaluation, which disrupts evolution.  

=
So it's very important not to introduce any more randomness than 
absolutel=
y necessary.  Of course, in some domains, it is perhaps 
necessary.  Howeve=
r, it is quite difficult to determine when it is 
truly necessary because m=
any times a set of deterministic trials that 
are carefully arranged to rep=
resent the space of possible situations 
can be a sufficient substitute for=
 randomization.  If that is the 
case, the set of deterministic trials once=
 again are preferable.  
Randomness is never a good thing unless absolutely=
 necessary.

In the case of learning to go to a target, it is sufficiently =
easy 
that it will probably work either way.  It is probably easier for the=
 
experimenter to do it with some randomness simply because that way we 
do=
n't have to introduce a bunch tedious hand-designed trials.  
However, too =
much randomness will indeed ruin the results because 
individuals may just =
happen to be near the target when they are born 
or when items on the field=
 are scrambled, though they deserve no 
credit.  

I would set it up someth=
ing like NERO:  Have a location where 
individuals are dropped onto the fie=
ld at random orientations yet far 
away from the ball.  Then keep the ball =
far away from where 
individuals start.  After a certain time period on the=
 field, an 
individual should be sent back to the starting point.  That way=
, 
nobody can hog the ball just by sitting next to it.

ken


In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, "Colin Green" <locster01@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> On 09/01/2008=
, Faisal Abidi <fabidi@...> wrote:
> 
> > What we're trying to teach the ne=
tworks is to get closer to the 
ball. robocup soccer server
> > (rcss) allo=
ws our agents to have access to relative distance and 
angle (relative to t=
he
> > player's facing) of the ball.
> > With these as the inputs we want t=
he network to minimize the 
angle (0 means dead-on)
> > and the distance. T=
he closer the angle and distance to 0 the 
greater the fitness.
> 
> It sho=
uld be easy enough for NEAT to find a solution I think.
> 
> 
> > Currently=
, we're running the simulation in realtime (couldn't 
figure out a simple w=
ay to
> > speed up game time on server end:S) with 10 players (the 
populat=
ion) in the sim. Each is
> > oblivious to the other, as the only objective =
is to close in on 
the ball.
> 
> The realtime limit is unfortunate, but th=
en the subtask of moving to
> the ball should be straightforward for NEAT -=
 depending on how the
> agent moves around I suppose.
> 
> 
> 
> > Every 10=
0ms (once again, a realtime server limitation) for each 
of the networks we=
 set
> > inputs and get outputs and perform the decided action.
> > We repe=
at the above NumActions times in EvalPop summing the 
fitness from each tri=
al.
> >
> > Now for the questions:
> > 1. On each subsequent call to EvalPo=
p, should we reset the 
positions (random positions
> > far from ball) and =
stats of the networks.
> 
> Yeh I think you need some degree of randomness =
in there otherwise 
you
> will probably just find a solution that only deal=
s with attacking 
the
> ball from a certain angle or some other limited sub=
set of possible
> scenarios. The prey capture experiment you mention actual=
ly tests 
each
> genome 100(I think) times per evaluation, each from a diff=
erent 
random
> starting point, roughly equidistant from the prey.
> 
> I w=
ould suggest you need to activate for a number of timesteps until
> (A) The=
 ball is reached or (B) a max number of timesteps is reached.
> You can the=
n assign fitness as something like  (CONST_MAX_FITNESS -
> distance - times=
teps_took). The constant term in there is required
> because SharpNeat can =
only maximise a fitness score right now, not
> minimise. So as the distance=
 falls you want the fitness to go up.
> 
> 
> > 3. Why does the GenomeList.=
Count vary? I noticed the same thing 
in preycapture. On
> > the 2nd call t=
o eval pop the count will be 1 extra, and a few 
hundred gens later it redu=
ced
> > to 1 less than the specified count. How can I disable this?
> 
> It=
's a side effect of the fitness sharing technique in SharpNEAT -
> each spe=
cies is assigned a new size based on it's fitness in the 
last
> generation=
. That new size is based on a species' proportion of the
> total population=
 size - and in calculating each species' size 
rounding
> occurs. So if the=
 allocation was 6.5 the species actually gets 7
> genomes. Thus you can exp=
ect at maximum 1 extra genome per species 
(I
> think). I suppose you could=
 disable speciation by setting the target
> species sizes to 0 (this might =
break the code but you can try it) 
and
> also setting a high initial compa=
rison threshold value.
> 
> Alternatively you could ignore any excess genom=
es by assigning them 
a
> zero fitness. It means you will miss the occasion=
al good genome, but
> it's not the end of the world.
> 
> Good Luck,
> 
> C=
olin.
>
